Editor-year-end-

Education Outlook for 20/20

COMMUNITY FOUNDATION OF PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND

Heritage Cemetery Network 

 Background




On a number of occasions community leaders have expressed concern about the care of cemeteries throughout the Island, especially cemeteries not directly attached to an active church; the most recent being on Monday with heritage activist, Dr. Catherine Hennessey.




The concerns are twofold.  One concern is that of the actual physical care and maintenance – lawn, fences, shrubs, sunken graves, signage, etc.  The other is concern about the ability to recruit future trustees.  Regarding the latter, it was pointed out that many trustees are often carrying on a family tradition, are aging and, with the out migration of people from rural areas, new trustees are becoming difficult to recruit.




Concept  

The concept is of a Heritage Cemetery Network, (HCN) as a not-for-profit organization whose main purpose would be to offer care and maintenance of heritage cemeteries.  Funds could come from many sources and the organization would seek registration as a charitable organization thereby allowing it to receive and receipt donations. 

Individual cemeteries would enter into an agreement whereby, for a fee,  HCN would provide maintenance services.  The costs of maintenance could be met in a variety of ways;

The local community could raise funds annually for the purpose

Families with relatives in the cemetery could pay an annual fee

Interested people and organizations could establish endowments for the purpose

Existing surplus funds and trusts could be used to establish endowments with CFPEI

Proposal 

CFPEI proposes to establish a commission to explore the idea further and to make recommendations. 							2010-02-02

title: 500 NZQA
summary: Don documents the New Zealand Qualifications Framework developed to address fragmentation in their qualifications system—gaps in recognized qualifications, unclear pathways, lack of prior learning recognition, and inconsistent terminology. The framework's key principles include simplification, open pathways with credit portability, promotion of lifelong learning with no distinction between general and career education, and performance-based assessment against national standards. The framework spans eight levels from primary through advanced degrees, with National Certificates recognizing levels 1-4, National Diplomas levels 5-7, and advanced qualifications at level 8. Units of Learning form the building blocks, each with credit ratings and standards including performance criteria, benchmarks, and elements. Schools are accredited and monitored for teaching quality.

DACUM







	DACUM has come a long way since the first analysis was undertaken in Ottawa in January of 1968.  For people not familiar with the term, DACUM is an acronym for Design A Curriculum and is a widely accepted approach to identifying competencies being practiced or to be learned – and it is no longer limited to an analysis of traditional occupations. And it is a Canadian idea at that.

 

DACUM is most widely used  as a rigorous, relevant, inexpensive and internally consistent approach  to identifying competencies in a field or occupation.  A major strength is the reliance on practitioners as the major source of information and a presentation of the competencies of a field on a single sheet..  As a result, DACUM escapes the semantics of the academic.  It is life based rather than research based and, therefore, is readily understood by people in the field since it reflects what they do and is stated in a language that the field understands.




The performance-based rating scale proposed by Adams is unique.  It includes all the required elements of a good rating scale ─ competencies, performance criteria, a scale, and benchmarks.  While it does not have rubrics or exemplars, they can easily be prepared.  On the other hand, it has benchmarks (industry-based ones) which are missing in most other assessment systems I’ve seen.  In my reading and discussion, I have not found an assessment system as complete.




A DACUM analysis is a tremendous tool for identifying and planning learning resources.  For each competency, one can identify the kind of human resource expertise required; facilities, equipment and supplies; appropriate learning activities; assessment techniques and strategies; and the best location for learning whether it be a classroom, laboratory, shop or actually in a real work situation.

Issues in public education

Guardian

	For some time now, I have engaged Islanders in conversations about public education, learning paths, continuing education, citizen math, curriculum development, professional autonomy and accountability, politicization, transition to employment and the list goes on. 

	My own view of education is quite simple.  Learning is a very personal matter and is about people changing the way they think, feel and act; education is about people helping  other people change the way they think, feel or act and a good education is about developing skills, knowledge and attitudes needed to function as a member of a democracy. The concept proposes an independent, private sector-driven body with authority to assess and certify performance on tasks found in occupations or fields. ATLANTIC PROVINCES QUALIFICATION AUTHORITY







Background




The acquiring of an education and the certification of qualifications are two separate functions although the two are closely linked and frequently one is thought to be the other.  The fact that the delivery of both functions is, to a large degree, provided or driven by educational institutions often works to the individual’s disadvantage in terms of both education and certification.  While separate certification bodies exist, they appear to place undue emphasis on results of study and too little emphasis on what has been learned outside the formal education system.




Concept




The idea behind this proposal is to establish an independent, private sector driven body with authority to assess and certify a person’s level of performance on a task or set of tasks such as found in an occupation or field.




Characteristics




AQUA will:




Be an independent organization with its own governing structure

Operate on a fee for service basis

Accept clients on direct application or by referral

Issue certificates based on demonstrated performance

On request, provide applicants with information on gaps to be filled to meet certification requirements. 

Make extensive use of advisory/working panels.




Benefits/Advantages




It is anticipated that the availability of AQUA will:




Remove barriers to certification encountered in the current approach

Focus certification more clearly on performance

Encourage more self study

Allow educational providers to focus on the teaching function

content_preview:
Education 20/20 – Montague Public Session – Feb 18, 2014 – from Steve McQuaid

Discussion points and observations

Key discussion point – young people not being well prepared academically 

  
Secondary school graduates – not prepared well in terms of literacy and numeracy skills, and work ethic 
  
This is reflected at PS level in need for ‘transition’ courses for incoming students – but not a big uptake by students – cost a factor?? 
  
20% of students leave in first year - only 3/5 move on through graduation 


Why is this happening – why lack of preparedness and follow through? 

  
Not a culture of learning within education 
  
The current structure does not support those few teachers who may want to try a different course – who are trying to focus on learning and are trying to engage students 
  
Students not challenged, not expected to ‘work hard’ to achieve – and so students over time choose the ‘easy route’ course – schools/teachers end up ‘passing kids through the system 
  
Possible solution – placed a higher value on learning, focus on student’s intuitive ‘learning style’, more project based learning opportunities 


However....

  
The whole education/learning context and culture would need to dramatically change...not sure if there is the political will to strive for this shift... there would be a lot of forces ...stakeholder bias and interests, etc, that would make this hard to accomplish

summary: (166 words):** Don challenges Canada's credential obsession, noting that displayed degrees tell little about actual competence. He critiques how institutions award credentials based on pre-set programs that may not reflect real occupational requirements. Don distinguishes between degrees, diplomas, and certificates, finding transcripts more useful than general credentials.
